newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta shares ignore Iraq news, end sharply up.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta shares ignore Iraq news, end sharply up.

text.p: Jakarta share prices closed sharply up on Wednesday on foreign buying of selected big-capitalised stocks and active local buying of small stocks, brokers said.
The Jakarta Composite Index rose 5.46 points, or 1.01 percent to 546.00 points. Gainers led losers by 70 to 26, with 43 counters unchanged.
Brokers said the market appeared to shrug off news of the second U.S missile attack on Iraq with more foreign buyers entering the market in late trade.

"It seems the U.S and Iraq news had only a mild impact on the region and improved market sentiment in regional markets gave a little confidence to foreigners here," said Budianto Wijaya of PT DBS Securities Indonesia.
But another broker said overall sentiment is volatile as global markets remain directionless.
"Many operators are waiting for upcoming U.S economic data for clues whether the U.S Federal Reserve would hike interest rates or leave it unchanged," he added.
Telecommunications heavyweight Telkom, cement producer Semen Gresik and cigarette maker Gudang Garam were among the stocks targeted by foreigners.
Semen Gresik rose 175 rupiah to 6,325 on a volume of 759,000 shares. Brokers said the rise was due to reports saying cement prices had risen in some parts of Indonesia following tight supply.
Medium-sized stocks, including Bakrie Brothers and Citatah, were also actively traded. Brokers said some investors were shifting their portfolios and both stocks were favoured.
Plantation and telecommunications company Bakrie Brothers rose 19.35 percent, or 450 rupiah, to 2,775 on a turnover of 7.7 million shares. Brokers said the rise was due to strong first-half results.
Lippo Securities and Lippo Life, both owned by the Lippo Group conglomerate, were also actively traded on plans by both for rights issues, brokers said.
Lippo Securities topped the active list with 9.3 million shares, rising 100 rupiah to 1,425 rupiah.
